Defect.Field:
The tcam dev_object code in the cpp driver defines DEV_STRICT_TYPE_CHECKING as the dev_object spec requires but it also includes the GTM header files which in turn include the system header files which is a violation of the dev_object model.
As a result, under IOX we get build failures of the nature:
cc1: warnings being treated as errors In file included from inc/c12k-rp-os/gtm/gtm_platform.h:24, from inc/c12k-rp-os/gtm/gtm_defs.h:17, from inc/c12k-rp-lc/cpp/oslib/cpp_gtm.h:22, from cpp/driver/server/cmn/src/cpp_drv_tcam4_dev_object_cmn.c:24: inc/c12k-rp-os/os/unistd.h:42: warning: useless keyword or type name in empty declaration inc/c12k-rp-os/os/unistd.h:42: warning: empty declaration inc/c12k-rp-os/os/unistd.h:52: warning: useless keyword or type name in empty declaration inc/c12k-rp-os/os/unistd.h:52: warning: empty declaration
As a temporary workaround the DEV_STRICT_TYPE_CHECKING define was removed but this needs to be fixed long term.
Ignored due to $$IGNORE, $$PREFCS or other ignore flags

Note.Field:
Portions of an email thread where the solution is discussed. Basically, the gtm_platfom.h header file needs to have avoid including any platform specific headers if GTM_DEV_STRICT is defined.
I recommend bracket the bulk of the file with an ifndef like:
#ifndef GTM_DEV_STRICT <original file contents> #endif /* GTM_DEV_STRICT */
That way, even if new platforms are added, GTM_DEV_STRICT will still prevent use of types that devobj doesn't like.
-Kev (kephilli)
On 1/23/06 5:19 PM, Markus Hoerler (mhoerler@cisco.com) wrote:
> > > > Agreed. I think Kevin's proposal is a bit cleaner, because it's > > clearer that this is not exactly another OS type, but something a bit > > different. But in the end, both will work. > > > > Assuming that Paul is the owner of that code (or the closest to an > > owner I know of at the very least), I'll go with whatever he feels > > most comfortable with. > > > > Thanks, > > Markus > > > > On Mon, 23 Jan 2006, Jian Ma (jianma) wrote: > > >> >> I think both suggestions from Kevin and Paul will work fine, if we were >> >> to take Paul's suggestion, we just sort of have another 'OS type' which >> >> is OS agnostic, and we make clear comments that it must precede all OS >> >> specific includes. Then these two proposals should work the same. >> >> >> >> Thanks >> >> Jian >> >> >>> >>> -----Original Message----- >>> >>> From: Kevin Phillips (kephilli) >>> >>> Sent: Monday, January 23, 2006 10:29 AM >>> >>> To: Paul Therrien (therrien) >>> >>> Cc: Markus Hoerler (mhoerler); Jian Ma (jianma); Keith >>> >>> Mitchell (kamitch); cpp-driver(mailer list); Rick Ruby (rickruby) >>> >>> Subject: Re: GTM includes are platform specific >>> >>> >>> >>> Paul, >>> >>> >>> >>> I think that should work as long at it were guaranteed to >>> >>> come first... >>> >>> obviously, we would not want to take the IOX, BinOS case, or >>> >>> any other if the GTM_DEV_STRICT (or whatever) was set. That >>> >>> said, I think I'd prefer to have it outside of the main set >>> >>> of cases just to minimize the maintenance risk when adding >>> >>> new cases... >>> >>> >>> >>> -Kev >>> >>> >>> >>> Paul Therrien wrote: >>>> >>>> I see, OK. Thanks for clarifying. >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> So why not simply add another section within >>> >>> gtm_platform.h, for example: >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> ... >>>> >>>> #elif defined(GTM_DEV_STRICT) >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> // include nothing >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> #elif defined(SOMETHING_ELSE) >>>> >>>> ... >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> Then, from within the context of your compiles, you can >>> >>> simply define >>>> >>>> this constant and no other code needs to change. >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> Comments? >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> Thanks, >>>> >>>> -- Paul >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> On 1/23/06 1:12 PM, Kevin Phillips (kephilli@cisco.com) wrote: >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>>> >>>>> Paul, >>>>> >>>>> >>>>> >>>>> As Markus points out the problem is the incompatibility of our >>>>> >>>>> dev_object code with gtm_platform.h. To be dev_object >>> >>> compliant, we >>>>> >>>>> need to define __DEV_STRICT_TYPE_CHECKING__. This causes >>> >>> dev_object >>>>> >>>>> headers to "undefine" a bunch of types that it considers >>> >>> "bad", like >>>>> >>>>> "int", thereby encouraging you to use "int32_t". Without >>> >>> these types >>>>> >>>>> (e.g. int, etc.), declarations inside unistd.h and others >>> >>> fail. So >>>>> >>>>> it is not a matter of adding things, to be compliant, we >>> >>> need to make >>>>> >>>>> sure that headers making use of these "bad" types are not >>> >>> included. >>>>> >>>>> Hence the suggestion of conditionally including them. >>>>> >>>>> >>>>> >>>>> -Kev >>>>> >>>>> >>>>> >>>>> Paul Therrien wrote: >>>>> >>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> Thanks for the clarifications, Markus. >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> I must say, however, that I still don't understand. >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> Looking at gtm_platform.h in pd-fwd.lu/latest: >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> #if defined(GTM_IOX) >>>>>> >>>>>> /* >>>>>> >>>>>> * IOX >>>>>> >>>>>> */ >>>>>> >>>>>> #include <unistd.h> >>>>>> >>>>>> #include <inttypes.h> >>>>>> >>>>>> #include <infra/boolean.h> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> #elif defined(GTM_UNIX) >>>>>> >>>>>> .... >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> I don't see anything here that makes use of "illegal" types. >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> Could it be that when you compile, GTM_IOX is not defined? >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> If this is a compile issue when running the compiler >>> >>> itself, as you >>>>>> >>>>>> suggest, then it seems to me that the solution lies in >>> >>> rearranging >>>>>> >>>>>> the contents of gtm_platform.h as appropriate, rather >>> >>> than modifying >>>>>> >>>>>> the rest of the library (and perhaps cause >>> >>> order-of-includes or other issues in your code as well). >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> Comments? >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> Thanks, >>>>>> >>>>>> -- Paul >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> On 1/23/06 12:02 PM, Markus Hoerler (mhoerler@cisco.com) wrote: >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> On Mon, 23 Jan 2006, Paul Therrien wrote: >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> Folks, >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> Please correct me if I'm wrong, but that header file >>> >>> does nothing >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> but declare those types. It doesn't actually use them >>> >>> to define anything. >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> You mean gtm_platform.h? That's correct. In fact, it >>> >>> just includes >>>>>>> >>>>>>> OS-specific header files which define types used elsewhere. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> So why does this become a problem? Is this due to some >>> >>> lint-type >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> tool that complains? >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Kind of. It's actually the way the dev_object files get compiled >>>>>>> >>>>>>> with strict type checking. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> Am I missing something? >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Here is what happens with the strict checking in >>> >>> dev_object: most >>>>>>> >>>>>>> of the data types which are typically causing problems are >>>>>>> >>>>>>> #define'ed to an empty string. For instance "#defined int". This >>>>>>> >>>>>>> very nicely catches every declaration of a >>> >>> variable/field/parameter which uses "int" >>>>>>> >>>>>>> instead of, say, the posix "int32_t". >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> So all these IOX-specific header files included from >>> >>> gtm_platform.h >>>>>>> >>>>>>> now define structs, prototypes and the like which are >>> >>> syntactically >>>>>>> >>>>>>> invalid, and the fact that they are not used really >>> >>> doesn't matter. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Kevin had the idea of reordering the includes in our >>> >>> driver file (i.e. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> include gtm_defs.h/gtm_drv_api.h first, then include >>> >>> dev_master.h >>>>>>> >>>>>>> for the dev_object stuff), which seems to work, but it >>> >>> does raise >>>>>>> >>>>>>> questions about the long-term maintainability of our code which >>>>>>> >>>>>>> have to be weighed against similar concerns in the GTM code. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> Regarding Markus' suggested solution: >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> Your suggestion won't work, since gtm_drvr_api.h >>> >>> already includes >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> gtm_defs.h, which in turn includes gtm_platform.h. >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Good point! So we would have to do something a bit more involved. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Given that there are currently 18 non-CPP source files >>> >>> in IOX (at >>>>>>> >>>>>>> least in the lineup I'm looking at), we probably don't want to >>>>>>> >>>>>>> change gtm_drv_api.h itself. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> So in addition to creating gtm_defs_only.h with the guts of >>>>>>> >>>>>>> gtm_defs.h, we would also have to move the guts of >>> >>> gtm_drv_api.h to >>>>>>> >>>>>>> gtm_drv_api_minimal.h and have gtm_drv_api_minimal.h include >>>>>>> >>>>>>> gtm_defs_only.h . >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> The point would be to create a minimal include file for the few >>>>>>> >>>>>>> driver files (just one for CPP right now) which require the >>>>>>> >>>>>>> stricter rules from dev_object. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> The intent behind gtm_platform.h was to provide each target >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> environment with a place in which to prepare the necessary >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> platform/target specific constructs. I'd much rather >>> >>> not change >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> the include structure, because it ultimately has a >>> >>> ripple effect >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> in a lot of files. >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> We are certainly trying to minimize the ripples. In >>> >>> fact, having to >>>>>>> >>>>>>> change both gtm_defs.h and gtm_drvr_api.h already makes >>> >>> me want to >>>>>>> >>>>>>> look for better alternatives. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> Couldn't you simply add a "#elif GTM_BINOS" block within that >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> file, and prepare the relevant dev_object-compliant >>> >>> content from there? >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> The problem is not a BinOS problem, it exists in IOX as well. In >>>>>>> >>>>>>> fact, BinOS actually pulls in fewer platform header files in >>>>>>> >>>>>>> gtm_platform.h, so the dev_object code compiles without errors. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> It's IOX which doesn't work. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> The problem is that compiling the dev_object-compliant >>> >>> driver code >>>>>>> >>>>>>> requires the type definitions from gtm_defs.h and >>> >>> gtm_drv_api.h but >>>>>>> >>>>>>> stumbles over the extra stuff from gtm_platform.h. We >>> >>> would like a >>>>>>> >>>>>>> way to 'un-include' gtm_platform.h, but that doesn't work in C. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Note that pretty much all the TCAM related CPP Client >>> >>> code (written >>>>>>> >>>>>>> by >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Jian) which includes gtm_defs.h does indeed need >>> >>> gtm_platform.h . >>>>>>> >>>>>>> It's just the driver code which has a problem. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> In other words, why sould the definitions intended for one >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> platform violate those used for yours? >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> It's not an issue with the definitions for one OS >>> >>> causing a problem >>>>>>> >>>>>>> with another. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> If this issue arises indeed from a lint-style tool that is >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> flagging errors, then I posit that the tool is deficient if it >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> ignores preprocessor directives...the defines and >>> >>> requirements of >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> one platform should not dictate how another platform >>> >>> prepares its >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> platform dependent information. >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> It's not a separate tool. It's the compiler itself. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> I'm definitely open to suggestions, but at the same >>> >>> time I want to >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> "do the right thing" for the long-term usability of this code. >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Same goal here. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Kevin suggested another alternative. Since the root cause of the >>>>>>> >>>>>>> problem is including things through gtm_platform.h which >>> >>> we don't >>>>>>> >>>>>>> need in the driver and which are harmful, what about >>> >>> letting the .c >>>>>>> >>>>>>> files specify through a #define that the whole gtm_platform.h >>>>>>> >>>>>>> should be effectively ignored? This would look like this >>> >>> in gtm_platform.h: >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> #ifndef __GTM_PLATFORM_H__ >>>>>>> >>>>>>> #define __GTM_PLATFORM_H__ >>>>>>> >>>>>>> #ifndef GTM_PLATFORM_SKIP_OS_INCLUDES >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> <guts of file> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> #endif /* GTM_PLATFORM_SKIP_OS_INCLUDES */ #endif /* >>>>>>> >>>>>>> __GTM_PLATFORM_H__ */ >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> In fact, if we didn't dislike cutesy hacks causing long-term >>>>>>> >>>>>>> maintenance problems, we could just use #define >>> >>> __GTM_PLATFORM_H__ >>>>>>> >>>>>>> in our driver file. :-) >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Thanks, >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Markus

Go ahead and mark it 'C.'
Thanks, -- Aziz
